rows.title: Introducing the Programme & Setting Goals
rows.introduction: The goal of this session is to introduce the program to participants and to help them define relationship strengthening and behaviour change goals that they would like to achieve by the end of the program.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Defining and setting goals.
* Learning how to set goals.
* Setting goals as a family.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* Flip chats, paper, pens, markers, crayons, Prestik.
* Name tags.
* Printed copies of session illustrations.
* House of support.
rows.drop_down_content_3:
* Welcome and Session Preps (30 minutes).
* Session Overview (30 minutes).
* Core Lesson (60 minutes).
* Session Close (30 minutes).
rows.message_text_1: Greetings Parents! I look forward to meeting you this week. We will be meeting at...(add in your name, organization, and the meeting time and location).
rows.message_text_2: Greetings Parents! Thank you for a wonderful session. A reminder this week that your home activity is to review your goals and share them with other family members. Also remember to do the physical exercise. You‚Äôre doing great!
rows.task_list_content:
* Confirm venue
* Venue Preparation
* Remind parents of the meeting time
* Organise drinks and snacks
* Consider bringing in a parent & their teen who have undergone the programme and can share their experience with the new families.
rows.title_button: Session 0: Introducing the Programme & Setting Goals

rows.title: Safeguarding Information
rows.introduction:
Please familiarise yourself with the following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **Understand abuse, neglect and exploitation.**
‚ùó **Abuse** refers to a deliberate act of maltreatment that can damage a child‚Äôs security, wellbeing, dignity and development. Abuse includes all forms of physical, sexual, psychological and emotional maltreatment. (Save the Children definition)
‚ùó **Violence** against children is defined as forms of physical or mental violence, damage and abuse, neglect or neglectful treatment or maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. (Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1990,Article 19)
‚ùó **Child exploitation** refers to using the child for economical or sexual benefit, for gratification or profit, often resulting in unjust, cruel and harmful treatment of the child. (Save the Children definition)
2Ô∏è‚É£ **Know your organisation‚Äôs child safeguarding policies and referral procedures.**
üìñ All organisations should have or develop child rights safeguarding policies and referral procedures, including details on how to respond appropriately when a parent or child discloses abuse.¬†
üìù You should have accurate knowledge of all protocols and response plans. These will tell you what to do within your organisation if a parent or child reports abuse (e.g. who to report to, internal resources for supporting the child), as well as how to engage outside resources (e.g. local referral pathways, when to engage with authorities).¬†
üîë It is your responsibility to act regardless of whether you are responding to disclosures of past and/or present abuse. However, you are not responsible for resolving the situation on your own. It is important that you discuss the situation with your supervisor to agree on what steps to take next.
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Ensure parents know that you are someone who can help.**
üå∑Parents participating in your sessions need to know that they can come to you for help, regardless of when abuse occurred.¬†
üëÇYou should make sure that they know that they can trust you and that you will listen and support them without judgement or any further harm.

rows.title: Family Goals & One-on-One Time
rows.introduction:
The goal of the session is to introduce participants to the concept of spending time together.

By spending time together parents and adolescents get to know each other and are able to relate better as they learn how to share experiences together.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Spending time makes us get to know each other better.
* Spending quality time provides us an opportunity to communicate to each other our needs and wants.
* Spending time strengthens the bond between a parent and a child.
* Spending time helps us pay attention to each other‚Äôs interests.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* Flip charts, paper, pens, makers, prestick.
* Attendance register.
* Name tag materials.
* Printed session illustrations (‚ÄúWhatsApp Quality Time‚Äù).
rows.message_text_1: Greetings Parents! I look forward to meeting you this week. We will be meeting at...(add in your name, organization, and the meeting time and location).
rows.message_guidance_1: Don‚Äôt forget to edit this and insert the next meeting time and location!
rows.message_text_2: Greetings Parents! Thank you for a wonderful session. A reminder this week that your home activity is to spend at least 15 minutes of your quality time together. Each day is about each other‚Äôs day and try to listen carefully. You‚Äôre doing great!
rows.message_guidance_2: Don‚Äôt forget to edit this and insert the next meeting time and location
rows.task_list_content:
* Prepare for the session with your work partner ( study the trust game).
* Remember to introduce the concept of role-playing and the characters.
* Prepare the venue.
* Gather all the necessary session materials.

rows.title: Keeping it Positive: Praise & Instructions
rows.introduction: Session 3 focuses on praising each other, This session will help cultivate positive behavior that comes with praise.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Praise helps to build positive relationships and brings out the behavior we want to see.
* Praise boosts self-confidence in adolescents.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* Flip chart
* Papers
* Pens,
* Markers,
* Name tags; 
* Attendance register,
* Printed copies of session illustrations.
rows.drop_down_content_3:
* The venue is clean
* Chairs are set, and participants will sit in a circle.
rows.message_title_1: Optional Mid-Week Reminder to Share After the Session
rows.message_text_1:
Great work this week, everyone! Our list of home activities is growing! Don't forget about the importance of one-on-one time this week and remember to focus on these home activities: 

‚úÖ Practice Praising your parent/teen at least 3 times a day. 
‚úÖ Praise yourself when you notice you are doing something good, too. You deserve it!
‚úÖ Parents: Notice how you give instructions and try to make them positive, specific, and realistic.
‚úÖ Teens: Remember to be calm and clear when talking to your parent about things that are important to you.
‚úÖ Do something nice to reward yourself for your hard work in the PLH Teens programme!
‚úÖ Spend at least 10 minutes of One-on-One Time each day with your teen/parent.
‚úÖ Take a Pause whenever you are feeling stressed or upset. You can even Take a Pause to appreciate a positive emotion!
‚úÖ Do the Physical Exercise every morning.
‚úÖ Meet with or contact (call or text message) your PLH Buddy one time during the week.
rows.message_text_3:
Thanks for sharing so many wonderful responses! üéâ¬†
Your child will be really happy if you get to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time each day. üòÉ
rows.task_list_content:
* It's important to notice the behavior
* Call the person you are praising by name and praise should be noticed and highlighted.
rows.title_button: Session 2: Keeping it Positive: Praise & Instructions

rows.title: Keeping it Cool: Managing Anger and Stress
rows.introduction: Session 4 focuses on talking about emotions, how to be aware and deal with them. Also how it helps in building stronger family relationships.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Talking about our emotions helps us control how we react or respond in difficult situations.
* Talking about our emotions helps develop awareness of our feelings and thoughts. 
* Talking about emotions helps us to move past difficult them and resolve conflicts better.

* Name tag materials

* Prepare all the materials that you will use during the group session
rows.message_text_2: Next week we will learn how to praise each other.
rows.faq_title: Key Issues to Be Aware Of
rows.title_button: Session 3: Keeping it Cool: Managing Anger and Stress

rows.title: Establishing Rules to Keep Healthy and Safe
rows.introduction: This session looks at how to manage our anger and stress when we find ourselves in difficult situations and to learn why it is important to communicate how we feel with the people around us.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* The goal of the session is for parents and adolescents to learn about how to manage anger in an effective way. Especially for parents, sometimes it can be difficult and frustrating when dealing with difficult adolescent behaviors.
* It is important that both parents and adolescents develop strategies that will help them respond to situations that make them angry in a more effective and non-aggressive way.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* Managing our anger helps us to control aggressive reactions towards a situation.
* Learning to manage our stress and anger can improve our situation and help us feel better.

rows.title: Keeping Safe in the Community & Responding to Crises
rows.introduction:
This week our main focus is helping parents build positive family relationships by being a supportive spouse and parent.¬†
The key building blocks for being a supportive spouse and parent are SHOW APPRECIATION, WORK TOGETHER, LEND A HAND, and ASK FOR HELP.¬†
1Ô∏è‚É£ **SHOW APPRECIATION**¬†‚öΩ Show your spouse that you appreciate it when they spend quality time with your children.¬†
2Ô∏è‚É£ **WORK TOGETHER**üòÉ Unsure how to work together with your spouse? Ask them!¬†‚úÖ By asking, you show that you care and want to be involved!¬†
3Ô∏è‚É£ **LEND A HAND**üëãIt can sometimes be difficult to remember to ask your spouse if they need help.¬†üí° Once you start asking, they may realise you want to be more involved and begin asking for your help on their own.¬†¬†¬†
4Ô∏è‚É£ **ASK FOR HELP**üòí It can be hard to ask for help. Sometimes we expect our spouses to know we need help even if we don‚Äôt ask them.¬†‚≠êOnce you start asking, they will likely start offering to help more in the future!¬†üíö Thank your spouse!
rows.title_button: Session 8: Keeping Safe in the Community & Responding to Crises

rows.title: Mobilisation and pre-group home visits
rows.introduction:
Mobilisation is a process of identifying parents/caregivers and adolescents for enrollment into HHPP.
Pre-group session visits give parents and adolescents the opportunity to learn more about the program and ask any questions about their involvement.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Identify community focal persons (e.g. clergy, school heads, health facility in-charge, neighborhood watch, market chairpersons, etc.).
* Identify and secure a venue for the meetings.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* Use the DREAMS local resource and community map. This is helpful in acquiring training venues and knowing your work community.
* Call or text participants in the DREAMS database made available.
rows.message_text_1: We are excited to invite you to our upcoming DREAMS HHPP parenting meeting, where we will be discussing valuable strategies for raising happy and healthy children.
rows.message_guidance_1: Remember to include the venue, date and time.
rows.message_text_2: Greetings Parents! Thank you for a wonderful session. A reminder this week that your home activity is to review your goals and share them with other family members. Also remember to do the physical exercise. You‚Äôre doing great!
rows.message_guidance_2: Remember to include the venue, date and time.
rows.message_text_3: We are sad not to have seen you during our first session. However, we would like to meet you at a place and time that is convenient for you. Thank you.
rows.message_guidance_3: Remember to mention that this message is from DREAMS HHPP.
rows.task_list_content:
* Set up the venue.
* Phone call or text reminders to participants.
* Prepare for the session.
* Carry the Home of Support poster.
* Arrive an hour before the session start time.
rows.title_button: Session 10: Mobilisation and pre-group home visits

rows.title: Managing time in a session
rows.introduction: As facilitators it is very important to ensure that we keep to the time of the session.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Send reminders to participants a day before the session.
* Prepare materials.
* Arrive at least 30 minutes-1 hour before the session starting time.
* Set Planning time before the session.
*Venue preparation.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* Welcome (15 Minutes)
* Overview (40 Minutes)
* Physical Exercise (5-10 Minutes)
* Game and Activity (15-25 Minutes)
* Core Lesson (50-60 Minutes)
* Energiser (5-10 Minutes)
* Home Activity (10-15 Minutes)
* Closing (10 Minutes)
rows.title_button: Session 11: Managing time in a session

rows.title: Leading a Role Play
rows.introduction:
Role plays are an educational technique that are used in the HHPP to convey specific information using real life situations.
Facilitators act out both negative and positive role plays.
rows.drop_down_header_1: Steps of leading a role play
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Introduce the activity.
* Read the heading and summary of the role-play.
* Act out the role-play.
* Ask questions in the manual.
*Praise participants.
rows.drop_down_header_2: Tips of leading a role play
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* The facilitator always acts out the role-play.
* Always act out the role plays in a circle.
* Clearly show emotions that are indicated in the role-play.
* Do the role play exactly as described in the manual.
* Some role plays require 3-4 characters. Ask and prepare specific participants before the session.
rows.drop_down_content_3:
* Negative role plays
* Positive role plays
* Open role plays

rows.title: Accept
rows.introduction: Acceptance is one of the main communication skills used in the Healthy Homes Parenting Program (HHPP).It is one way to show that the views and emotions of participants are welcome.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Participants feel empowered to share when facilitators accept whatever is said during a discussion. There is no wrong answer. 
* Facilitators can show that they have really heard the participant by repeating what the participant says to the entire group. 
* This also makes sure that the facilitators understand what is being said.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* Accept by showing that you are listening and acknowledging how brave it can be to speak about issues relating to HIV and AIDs that may be affecting families in the homes and communities they live in.
* Accept by showing that you understand and respect whatever feelings participants express. Remember to praise participants for being brave when they share feelings.
* Accept by reminding participants that it is important that they know they are in charge of telling or talking about their experience. The workshop is a safe for exploring different ways of talking about HIV and AIDS experience.
* Accept by reminding participants that they can say as little or as much as they want. They don‚Äôt have to answer questions that may be seemingly sensitive if they don‚Äôt want to.
rows.drop_down_content_3:
* Nodding 
* Eye Contact 
* Paraphrasing 
* Body Posture 
* Praising participants

rows.title: Explore
rows.introduction: Explore is one of the main communication skills used in the Healthy Homes Parenting Program (HHPP). Exploration is one of the techniques used in HHPP to enquire more information.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Exploring in the Home of Support can create a sense of belonging.
* It enables participants to share knowledge skills and perspectives,l eading to better decision-making. 
* It also enhances problem-solving and provides emotional support.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* We explore by asking participants open-ended questions guided by words such as What, Why, Where, When, and Who.
* Note: Always remind participants that there is no right or wrong response to what they share in the group.
 * Sometimes we need to ask questions that explore the details about something to understand it properly.
 * When participants share an experience, facilitators can ask questions like: Where? What? Who? and How? 
 * Often participants have difficulty exploring ‚Äì or asking themselves more questions about ‚Äì an experience. 
 * Example follow-up questions (from previous discussion): ‚ÄúWhere else do you think you could spend quality time together? Why do you think this worked well?‚Äù

rows.title: Connect
rows.introduction: Connecting is a facilitation skill used to link to positive experiences that participants share, expected scenarios and core principles of the program.
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Facilitators connect experiences that participants share to the session‚Äôs core principles. 
* In discussion with participants, the group may also make their own connections on how a certain experience might relate to the session.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
* We connect in sessions where participants discuss sharing emotions, collaborative problem solving and making long-term goals. This is particularly helpful in talking about HIV material.
* Connect to ‚ÄúTaking a Pause‚Äù when discussions feel stressful or difficult.

rows.title: Home visits & phone calls
rows.introduction:
Participants may miss a session or need additional support for different reasons. Whatever the reason is, it is important that they are caught up to help them build their skills and stay involved in the programme.
Building the skills of parents is the first focus of HHPP, as this creates healthy supportive family environments for teens. For follow-ups, it is therefore most important that the **parent is present**. Their teen(s) and other family members can also join the visit/call if they are available.
rows.drop_down_title: How to make follow-ups a success:
rows.drop_down_content_1: Brainstorm ideas with your participants by asking ‚ÄòSome of our group have missed this session, what can we do to get everyone updated?‚Äô. When ideas and suggested dates/times come from participants it is more likely that the solution will work well for them and that they will follow through.
rows.drop_down_content_2:
In HHPP, each participant is paired with a ‚Äòbuddy‚Äô. 
A buddy can share with a participant what they learned in the session. Even if you will still do a home visit afterwards, an update by the buddy will shorten the time you need for that home visit as you are only filling in the gaps.
To prevent the same person from missing another session, you can encourage the buddy to remind the participant of the upcoming session.
rows.drop_down_header_3: Do a joint home visit catch-up
rows.drop_down_content_3: When multiple participants have missed a session, you can invite them to come for a joint catch-up session at one of their homes. This is particularly helpful when participants stay closer together.
rows.drop_down_header_4: Do a phone call or WhatsApp call
rows.drop_down_content_4:
When participants have phones, you can give them a call to catch them up on a session missed.
If they have a smart phone with WhatsApp, you can catch them up via a WhatsApp call (or even a conference call so multiple participants can join one catch-up).
rows.drop_down_content_5: It can be hard to find parents or teenagers at home at times that work well for them and yourself. You can explore if you can visit them at their school or work place (office, farm land, etc.).

rows.title: Pre-group home visits
rows.drop_down_content_1:
* Ask participants what goal they would like to achieve during the programme
* Make the goals positive
* Make the goals realisable within 14 weeks
* ‚ÄúYour goal is to see your child go to university. Our programme is 14 weeks. Will your child be able to go to university in 14 weeks from now? Is there a quicker goal that can help your child go to university? [participant response] Yes, you can help your child so they improve their marks in school this semester.‚Äù
* Make the goals focused on the person sharing (instead of their parent/teen):
* ‚ÄúWhat can you do to help realise that goal?‚Äù (e.g. your goals is for your child to listen ‚Äì what can you do as parent?).
